reviews.review_msg: Made material very interesting, and workload was totally manageable. Had back problems during start of term and uploaded lecture recordings instead of doing lectures in person. Once he was back in person, he continued to upload lecture recordings which was very appreciated. Tests had me a bit tight on time, but overall W prof.

In my experience he seemed to care very much about the material and the students succeeding.  The assignments and tests were HEAVY but never surprising and instructions were detailed to the point of it almost being too much at times.  He was super approachable and legitimately seemed to care about students succeeding.  Very fair grader IMO

I took this course with Pascal in the fall of 2024. I wouldn't recommend this course, especially if you're looking to boost your GPA. The first assignment had an average of 68%, and the exams were tough as well. In the end, the professor added an extra 3% to everyone's final grade to boost the class average, but it didn't make a huge difference.

In my experience, He doesn't seem to be empathetic or understanding, as the REM department in general. If you are recovering from any injury or disability, this professor most likely will not work with you. Way too rigid and difficult. Other departments, Professors, and Universities are more open and helpful. Integrity is keeping your word.

Would not choose to take this again, the prof made it monotonous and your grade relies heavily on two major assignments, the midterm and final exam. Does not give the appropriate time to think during the exam, the questions full of additional questions, one question would have a through e to answer over 3 questions, giving you not much time either.
So much studying for an elective, I have never studied this much for this basic of a class. Do not take this class for an elective plz. I'm warning you

This class is way more trouble than it has any right to be for a 100-level course. The content itself is interesting, but the format sucks all the life out of it. Videos are dry and repetitive. Marking was unpredictable across assignments. Don't bother if you can help it.

**This is for prof Alexander Cancelli**.

Best part of the class(I will never forget this):

Had a 3% bonus to the 2 students who wrote the most discussion posts relating to current events (ex. Fire in Las Vegas). At the end, there were almost 4,000 discussion posts. At about 120 or 130 words, me and 2 others wrote about 500,000 words. Never forget

I think the course content itself is good; however, delivery of an online course should not be this difficult. There is not much time to think during the exams as have many stated. I am here to confirm that nothing changed ever since, for an online environment its a horrible course. Ps the course is not taught by Pascal but the same format.

Do not take this class if you are trying to take a GPA booster or as an elective. It had more work than my regular classes and was hard to do well. There is too much information to remember and they watch you zoom like an owl during exams. Avoid at all costs

Avoid REM100 AT ALL COSTS! Environment/sustainability was often a subject in my actual degree but this class has more work than my 400-level classes... Exams are anxiety ridden on a time crunch and questions are unforgiving. This is a GPA KILLER!

My instructor for REM 100 was not Pascal, but his slides and same curriculum was used. This class has so many terms and concepts that do not correspond together sometimes, making it a difficult class. Additionally, the examples he provide for a concept are very short-sighted and vague. They also lack in critical and interdisciplinary perspectives.
Do not take this course if you want a gpa booster. This course was a lot of work than needed and the exams were hard. It was a lot of work too try to stay away unless mandatory

Time constraints are a joke, even for an online class - you are watching us on zoom too! C'mon man. Waaay too much writing for a 100 level course, ~1500 word papers for the first assignment and second assignment, along with paragraphs for 2 group discussions each week, where's my W credit?? no wonder you cant attract ppl to the department.

Taking this class with Pascal was a good choice. The assignments were reasonable and online group discussions were easy. Pascal is always open to answering questions and wants students to understand the material well. However, the exams were tough - especially the time limit for multiple choice.

Pascal is a great professor. Video lectures were very organized and he takes time to thoroughly explain the material. Assignments took quite a bit of time to finish but were easy. His exams are a bit too long. Midterm/Final questions were fair but there were too many multiple choice q's. The final had too many sub-questions for the written portion.

REM100 online with Pascal was enjoyable. The learn at your pace videos were informative and surprisingly not boring. Beware of the the Final and Midterm however, as since it is an online course they prevent you from cheating by making the test extremely short. The questions themselves are reasonable but it's a race against time to complete them.

This class is Incredibly interesting and Pascal is a great teacher. He obviously wants the students to succeed and makes it pretty clear what he wants you to retain. His biggest pitfall is the exams. The time restraints are ridiculous, I did fantastic in everything besides the exams and that brought grade down even though I know the material.

good lectures and assignments; a perfect class except for the exams. The exams are unjust with an extremely short time limit. The final/midterm has 3 paragraph questions with 5+ sub-questions for each one and less than 30 minutes to complete them all. Not to mention an extremely long multiple choice portion with 30 seconds for each question.

This professor is amazing - Incredibly clear about what he wants us to know, interesting lectures, and considering this was an asynchronous class, I felt very connected to the class and the content. He goes above and beyond to ensure that he keeps up consistent contact and everyone feels comfortable with what is expected. Would HIGHLY recommend!

One of the best prof I have at SFU. Love his lesson so much and it is not a long lecture(3x 50 mins per week)
The content in this class is straightforward and easy to understand. Definitely recommended people take this class with him!
Great proffessor. Extremely knowledgeable and passionate about topics in class. Nothing but good things to say about Pascal.
He's a good professor but the exams are such little time for closed book. Answers are all very similar for the mc as well. If you have test anxiety don't take it with him.

Pascal passionate to subject:) Long info-filled lectures n readings. asgn (use sfu library articles) overall okay but exams difficult very short time limit with reliance on readings/findings/memorization with m/c n long answers n monitored synchronously. material interesting n resourceful to know but so much to learn in short time for intro class.

If it wasn't for the exams, this class would be perfect. Exam content was very fair, but they're online and invigilated through Zoom so there is barely enough time to read each question let alone answer them to the best of your abilities. Exams should be in person so they actually assess student's knowledge properly. Way too time contained online.

Pascal is a good prof who is very passionate about what he is teaching but his exams are unreasonable and extremely difficult. You are given an unrealistic time constraint during exams with questions that are worded weird and stray off from the actual course content. I would not recommend this course as a gpa booster.

Pascal is a nice professor but his tests just make no clear sense, during his final exam and midterm review he says random material which isn't even on the actual test. I took this class as an elective since people rated it as an easy class, but trust me this class is not an easy A class. DO NOT RECOMMEND HIM

This class is incredibly organized. Rubrics are provided for each assignment/discussion and lectures are clear and easy to understand. Each module explains the lesson outcomes and what to watch/do for that week and Pascal explains instructions as if you're a second grader so you know exactly how to go about doing assignments.

Pascale is honestly great. As someone with zero background in REM and who struggles with science courses, I am so pleased with how helpful and accessible he is. If you post a question on a discussion board, he usually answers within hours. Same thing with email. He really does want his students to do well and it shows!

Honestly one of the most amazing professors I've ever had. He is so passionate about what he is teaching and so kind and accommodating to students. He clearly puts a lot of work in to his lectures and modules. There was a lot of content to memorize, but that's typical. Overall really great.

Not much interaction with the prof as the class was pre recorded and online. The class however was super well prepared and the prof was always willing to help. I would reccomend him for anyone looking at taking Rem 100. A very useful and doable course. Put in some effort and you will easily get an A- or B+. He simplifies things

Pascal is a really good prof who is great at explaining the basic topics of REM and making sense of more complex topics in his lectures. Even though his class was online this semester, his lectures were super long and its super important that you take good notes as his slides don't cover everything. Lots of discussion posts and only exams!

I loved taking this course with Pascal. It is pretty lecture-heavy but he's very straightforward explains the material well. Tutorials were kind of a waste of time but the pre-tutorial discussions were easy credits. Assignments were also fairly graded. The canvas page and organization were confusing at times- but not a deal breaker.

Great prof., though he has strong personal opinions about things, he doesn't avoid sharing alternative viewpoints which is an extremely rare quality to find in profs these days. Highly recommend him in the department.

Loved REM 100 with Pascal Haegeli! Out of all my classes this semester, his was the best structured and easy to follow. He really cared about formatting his class in a way that students could understand. 10/10 would recommend!

Really inspiring guy. Super organized, and content is engaging and adapted to address current events whenever possible. Warning though, tests can be hard due to vague mc questions, and time constraint on written. Highly recommend.
Super kind! Would recommend :)

This is a good class, but little contact with the professor. I had a great TA which helped the experience. There are weekly discussions for easy marks, and one group project which is difficult considering the online format. I found the midterm straight forward and with proper prep it is an easy A-B.

Pascal is a fantastic professor. He cares deeply about his students, the class content, and his own work. REM 427 focuses on Avalanche Risk Management so it is beneficial to have some experience on the topic before hand. Pascal however, is one of the most respected figures in the industry so even without prior knowledge you are in a great position

Pascal is a wonderful professor; he inspired me to enter the REM program. His lectures demonstrate his high level of passion and commitment to REM and his research. I would recommend to anyone that they should take a course led by Pascal because he is an incredible speaker and makes you engage meaningfully!

Pascal's lectures can be pretty dry, not a lot of students show up. His powerpoints are also a bit messy and he can run out of time on many occasions. But he seems really passionate about what he is teaching. Midterm had a lot of stuff and it was a time crunch, final was not too bad. Make sure to memorize everything.

Interesting & easy course; relevant & important topics. Lectures could get interactive & fun. Projects were actually really interesting & enjoyable! Easy & straightforward exams. Short & easy readings online w/ reading guides. That said, tutorials were often boring & childlike, the Canvas page is AWFUL, & Pascal himself doesn't STAND OUT as a prof.

Pascal is a great choice in the Faculty of Environmental Science. He cares about the course content and wants his students to succeed. His expectations for achieving a good grade in the class are well laid out and straightforward. He speaks with a Swiss accent, but it was not difficult for me to understand.

its a lvl 100 course and making us do a LONG PAPER/CRITICAL REVIEW based on peer reviewed articles... don't take as an elective, i dont understand why ppl recommend this course as an elective and you have to do a such a long paper worth 25% of ur grade... DO NOT TAKE for elective

Pascal is a very kind professor and his lectures are very clean and organized. For REM100 at least, it can be a little lecture heavy, as we've had times when we were not able to finish the lecture and had to continue next day. There were interesting projects, debates and discussions in tutorials! If you study with effort, you'll get an A!

Good prof who is clearly passionate about global change. Slightly hard & picky marker. His midterm and exam had a lot of questions that we could barely finish in the time given because he wanted to "challenge" his students. Tutorials and assignments were very easy. Some exam questions were phrased badly so ask questions to clarify.

Really interesting course, knows his stuff and keeps the lectures interesting. Nothing too difficult about the course, read the notes and pay attention, do the assignments and you should be fine. Tutorials were interesting too.
Definitely passionate about his teachings, skim the slides and maybe the readings and you'll do fine, relatively easy A
Very nice man, good sense of humour, engaging lecture material,  great bloke.

Amazing prof, very passionate about global issues and spreads awareness. I've learned so much valuable information from Pascal and I would definitely take another class with him. Wants students to succeed, midterms were fair and tutorials were interactive and related. Readings could be lengthy but showed up on exams.

Pascal is a really nice guy. I missed the midterm due to an emergency and he let me redo it the next class. However, he marks really hard. Very high expectations for exams (aka wants you to memorize very specific things..).

Really enjoyed Pascal's lectures and format of the class. Was very straightforward about what he wanted. Inspired and taught me a lot about very important global issues! If people were unhappy, its because they thought it would be an easy A and didn't bother to study.

Regret not dropping the second he said he was a first time prof. If you can't recount word for word for his 100 mark 100% short answer test you will get 0 on the question, hardly any part-marks. Lectures were very boring and the assignments extremely unclear and marking was very uneven throughout tutorials.

I enjoyed taking REM100 with Dr. Haegeli. Lectures were clear and well-organized, with stated learning objectives at the beginning. Good use of visuals, media, and good presentation style (does not read off slides).  Expect to read about 15-30 pages/week.  Exams are easy if you attend lecture and do readings. Review learning objectives on CANVAS.

Lectures were clear and well-organized. Content flowed well, and were related to each other. Guest lectures were fantastic. Sometimes there wasn't enough time to cover the content which made some things unclear. Assignments were clear, but the short page limit makes it a bit difficult. Midterm was fair, but you really needed to know your stuff.

A very dry instructor, which is unfortunate because the material is important and could be presented in a far more engaging way. This was my least favourite class and I regret taking it this term with this instructor. Half the class failed the midterm because lectures and tutorials were all over the place. You had no idea what to study for.
Inconsistencies between requirements for assignments and marking. Put a lot of work into lectures, but overly critical of student work and made many assumptions on student prior knowledge.
